thebootfitter

My question posed for discussion is this:
 
 Is there fundamentally any distinction between a superstitious belief (i.e. breaking a mirror means seven years of bad luck) and a belief in a supernatural entity of some sort?

post_info.post_title: Difference between superstition & belief in God?

billsco

From my vantage point, no. It comes from the same transistor in the brain, IMO. 
 
 What is a bit surprising however, is how vocal some Christians are about any superstitions not associated with their particular faith. They are most diligent in stamping out and/or avoiding them.
Big Orn

It really depends on the person. Some who believe in God do so because they are taught to, thus making that belief a “false notion”.
 However, if every time I broke a mirror I experienced seven years of bad luck, then I couldn’t help believe it’s true. Right? If each time I walked under a ladder something bad happened, then I would definitely avoid doing so.
 
 If I pray to God for something, and believe it when I pray, and it happens, then would I not be inclined to believe in God and the power of prayer? Each person holds to a certain belief and to that person there has to be something to substantiate that belief or else soon they fall away from it. If I believe that God is a myth and never “try” Him, then my life will be based on that.
 
 To me Malachi 3:10, which says, ”Bring the whole tithe into the storehouse, that there may be food in my house. Test me in this," says the LORD Almighty, "and see if I will not throw open the floodgates of heaven and pour out so much blessing that you will not have room enough for it.”, is not a superstition, but truth – and it works. To others it is just a fable. So whatever works in your life to give you peace, comfort, and joy, should be your stronghold. The Lord is my stronghold and I have all the proof I need.
 
 
 So, I’m glad I don’t have to go outside, turn my pockets inside out, and count crows. :)
unkerpaulie

but ron, look at the basis of the superstition. "bad things"?? bad things happen all the time. and yet there is no such thing as a bad thing. if you want to visit the public pool, but find that the gate is locked, is that a bad thing? if you lose your job, is that a bad thing? if you get drafted into the marines, is that a bad thing? what superstition does is conditions your mind to interpret events as bad, even though you benfit more that suffer from those same events
Big Orn

but ron, look at the basis of the superstition. "bad things"?? bad things happen all the time. and yet there is no such thing as a bad thing. if you want to visit the public pool, but find that the gate is locked, is that a bad thing? if you lose your job, is that a bad thing? if you get drafted into the marines, is that a bad thing? what superstition does is conditions your mind to interpret events as bad, even though you benfit more that suffer from those same events

 Or something good: A robin flying into the house; sneezing 3 times before breakfast; meeting 3 sheep; looking at the new moon over your right shoulder, etc, etc.
 
 I suppose I gave some examples of bad, but it was just the first two that came to mind.
 
 Conditioning one’s life by a belief that proves itself to be true could be bad or good, depending on the person and/or the belief, I reckon. But to base one’s life on a belief that is never substantiated is a waste, IMO.
 
 Belief in God can be a superstition or a fact. That is what I was trying to point out. I think thebootfitter has a good point and could lead to some very frightening truths to many people. For instance a preacher of 50 years, on his deathbed, asking another preacher if there really is a God…
unkerpaulie

my point is, there is no such thing as "good luck" or "bad luck" except in our own preconditioned minds. any event could have beneficial or adverse long-term effects. and the effects themselves are only as beneficial or adverse as we precieve them to be. it has nothing to do with the event itself, only the outlook.
 
 the belief in God more or less creates that same sense of mental condition, but on a much larger scale. believe in God or you'll burn in hell forever. give your tithes and you'll be rewarded. etc.
Waxy

IMHO, the answer is NO.
 
 Waxy
Big Orn

my point is, there is no such thing as "good luck" or "bad luck" except in our own preconditioned minds. any event could have beneficial or adverse long-term effects. and the effects themselves are only as beneficial or adverse as we precieve them to be. it has nothing to do with the event itself, only the outlook.
 
 the belief in God more or less creates that same sense of mental condition, but on a much larger scale. believe in God or you'll burn in hell forever. give your tithes and you'll be rewarded. etc.

 I agree with you about the luck part. But, that thing in which we believe and base our life on does not care whether they are bad or good. Clear? I’m not saying that what I believe is better than what you believe or that it is worse, just that the gauge is constantly monitored – or should be. If it’s not then we can tumble with any old wind that blows.
 
 Remember Anastasia’s thread about memes? http://4forums.com/political/showthread.php?t=3003&highlight=meme
 
 And, yes, any event, good or bad, does affect us, but differently for me than you…maybe. It all boils down to how eager we are at finding out whether that belief or superstition holds water. Just to categorize two things that seem alike as identical depends on how you have tested the results. I have to agree that superstition and the belief in God can be similar notions to some people. But, similarity is not sameness. Similarity is a flexible, fluctuating, and pliable concept. Sameness is firm, unbreakable, and absolute. Two things, persons or ideas may share any number of similarities. That they are partners in similarity, by definition, makes them not the same. As a result, sameness and similarity are mutually exclusive concepts.
 I happen to know for a fact that some people who confess to be Christians and who call the Lord their God, believes in Him about as much as they do the Tooth Fairy.
 Still, to me, there is a vast difference between superstitions and the belief in God.
Waxy

Reminded me of a line in The Big Bounce -
 
 Morgan Freeman's character says something to the effect of - "God? What's God have do with it? God's just an imaginary friend for grown ups."
 
 I was suprised they'd throw a line like that into a light hearted comedy aimed at average Joe.
 
 It struck me as funny, and yet, oh so true. Pretty simple analogy, albeit a bit of a cutting one.
 
 We deride adults and question their sanity when they have imaginary friends, and dismiss it as harmless superstition or play for young children, and yet, talking to God is considered "normal".
 
 Waxy
Alan Ryan

I happen to know for a fact that some people who confess to be Christians and who call the Lord their God, believes in Him about as much as they do the Tooth Fairy.
 Still, to me, there is a vast difference between superstitions and the belief in God.

 I think I understood what you are driving at until I got to this bit. Can you
 say what are the differences between superstitions and a belief in God ?
Big Orn

Reminded me of a line in The Big Bounce -
 
 Morgan Freeman's character says something to the effect of - "God? What's God have do with it? God's just an imaginary friend for grown ups."

 Good one, Waxy. :p 
 
We deride adults and question their sanity when they have imaginary friends, and dismiss it as harmless superstition or play for young children, and yet, talking to God is considered "normal".
 
 Waxy

 But, when He talks back, and you admit it...get a straight jacket...
Waxy

Good one, Waxy. :p

 
 I wish I could take credit. :p 
 
 
He talks back, and you admit it...get a straight jacket...

 
 Yes and no. 
 
 GWB and others have publicly admitted to hearing the voice of God and acting on it.
 
 Now, if "god" tells you to break the law or start doing things outside the accepted "norm" of society, then yes, the straight jacket comes out in a hurry. Along with the insanity defense.
 
 Waxy
Big Orn

I think I understood what you are driving at until I got to this bit. Can you
 say what are the differences between superstitions and a belief in God ?

 Superstitions have no basis - you can search and dig and want it to be true, but it's just an empty belief.
 
 Belief in God - true belief - means testing God, seeing if He listens, then getting results. How long does that take? For some a lifetime. But, it all depends on how much you put into it and how much you get in return. Understanding/learning how to place yourself into position to do so is what the Bible is for.
Alan Ryan

Superstitions have no basis - you can search and dig and want it to be true, but it's just an empty belief.
 
 Belief in God - true belief - means testing God, seeing if He listens, then getting results. How long does that take? For some a lifetime. But, it all depends on how much you put into it and how much you get in return. Understanding/learning how to place yourself into position to do so is what the Bible is for.

 Sorry if this sounds a bit pedantic but before you can "test" God, don't you have to believe he exists first ? How do you separate this first order belief from a mere superstition ?
Big Orn

Sorry if this sounds a bit pedantic but before you can "test" God, don't you have to believe he exists first ? How do you separate this first order belief from a mere superstition ?

 Belief comes by hearing and hearing by the Word of God. Now, this is a whole new can of worms, Alan - and gets back to the “similar part” that thebootfitter was referring to (fishing for) ...eventually.
 To be certain what to believe you must first hear one or more ideas. In time you learn which ones will and will not work. How to learn depends on your willingness to do so. Being lazy about it will condemn (for the lack of a better word) you to remain in the realm of superstition.
 And getting to the core of the differences between superstitions and belief in God is anything but pedantic, IMO.
jitobear

From a purely academic stance - no.
 
 But academia isn't what faith is about anyway.
 
 
 

 What is a bit surprising however, is how vocal some Christians are about any superstitions not associated with their particular faith. They are most diligent in stamping out and/or avoiding them.

 
 Avoiding them is a Biblical directive. Stamping them out is overkill and innapropriate.
thebootfitter

If I pray to God for something, and believe it when I pray, and it happens, then would I not be inclined to believe in God and the power of prayer?

 Sure. But what happens when God does not answer the prayer in the same way we want God to answer the prayer? We can easily say that our way is not God's way. Some people suggest that "prayers are always answered... just not always in the way you expect them to be." Isn't it also reasonable to think that someone praying for something wants it to happen badly enough that they make it happen? If we were to conduct an objective test to measure whether prayer has any impact on reality, do you believe the results would be conclusive? I doubt it... but it would be an interesting experiment if it hasn't already been conducted.
 
 
 
But to base one's life on a belief that is never substantiated is a waste, IMO.

 By what measure can a belief in the supernatural be substantiated? Doesn't substantiate imply physical evidence or physical existence?
 
 Websters Main Entry: sub·stan·ti·ate 
 1 : to give substance or form to : EMBODY
 2 : to establish by proof or competent evidence : VERIFY 
 
 This implies that belief in God, by definition, can never be substantiated. It can only be accepted through faith. Individuals may offer their perceptions of personal experiences as evidence that establishes the existence of God, but replace one individual with another individual in the same set of circumstances, and you may get a completely different perception of the exact same personal experience.
 
 
For instance a preacher of 50 years, on his deathbed, asking another preacher if there really is a God...

 Ron, I'm curious whether this is an easily imagineable hypothetical, or if you are aware of a specific instance of this happening. My 97 year old grandmother died recently. She was a very spiritual woman -- spending many hours a day in prayer. She seemed to be struggling with 'letting go' toward the end, and I wondered whether she may have been dealing with this most fundamental question.
 
 
 
Superstitions have no basis - you can search and dig and want it to be true, but it's just an empty belief.
 
 Belief in God - true belief - means testing God, seeing if He listens, then getting results. How long does that take? For some a lifetime. But, it all depends on how much you put into it and how much you get in return. Understanding/learning how to place yourself into position to do so is what the Bible is for.

 You attempt to make a distinction here between superstition and belief in God. However... let's take the same thing in the context of a superstition that you said about 'true belief in God.' 
 
 For example, belief that touching a photo of a lost loved one everyday upon waking -- true belief -- will result in you spending a glorious, eternal afterlife with that person. So, you do this everyday, because you do not want to lose the opportunity to spend eternity with your loved one. It takes a lifetime of doing this to test whether or not it has any merit. Every once in awhile, you experience signs... like the smell of your loved one's favorite flowers at the very moment you were touching the photo or at the very moment you were thinking of the person. Or maybe life is getting you down, but then you think of your loved one and the prospect of spending a glorious eternity with them, and that thought alone cheers you up. Then one day, you forget to touch the picture, and you happen to get into a car accident. And you have a 'vision' of your loved one being sad because you forgot to touch the picture, but they reassure you in this vision that as long as you are truly sorry, you will be forgiven and you can still continue to touch the picture everyday, and everything will be okay.
 
 In this example the individual's experience can certainly be perceived to substantiate the belief of touching the picture = glorious eternity with loved one. How is this different than a belief in God?
unkerpaulie

Sorry if this sounds a bit pedantic but before you can "test" God, don't you have to believe he exists first ? How do you separate this first order belief from a mere superstition ?

 you dont have to believe that something is true before you test it. in everyday life its usually the opposite way around. with God, yes, it is required you have faith that he will "pass the test" before you test him. and even if you dont see the results you expect, you must still be totally convinced that he "passed the test"
Big Orn

Sure. But what happens when God does not answer the prayer in the same way we want God to answer the prayer? We can easily say that our way is not God's way. Some people suggest that "prayers are always answered... just not always in the way you expect them to be." Isn't it also reasonable to think that someone praying for something wants it to happen badly enough that they make it happen? If we were to conduct an objective test to measure whether prayer has any impact on reality, do you believe the results would be conclusive? I doubt it... but it would be an interesting experiment if it hasn't already been conducted.

 I know enough about you to know that you know the difference between fleecing and testing. But, I will try to explain the method of testing that I am familiar with. – and that by relating to this site.
 Once in one of the Gay Marriage threads I replied in a manner “off the top of my head”, which proved to be very devastating; not only to feelings but also to me, personally. I began to feel as though I was speaking from the head and not the heart and I was. In order to come to some knowledge beyond my normal/usual understanding I asked God to help me understand. It took awhile, but God put someone in my life (and I know it was from God, but there’s no proof) that gave me understanding – a little at a time. I saw me judging through the eyes of this person’s parents; saw me denigrating this young person through their actions. And they truly loved him, but had no understanding about this “problem”. Soon I began to love this person – not in a worldly way, but spiritually. In all other aspects of his life he was just like me…and here I was striving to be like Christ. So, the answer I got was not what I expected, but what I needed in order to understand. In that way God did answer my prayer and gave me more than I asked for.
 
 On the other hand if someone makes their “prayer” come true, then they have not actually heard from God. That’s a cut-and-dried situation. To pray for money, then win the lottery…well, they had to buy a ticket first. To pray for money and get an unexpected raise or unexpected bonus, who is to say God is not responsible. To pray for a mate, then go “get” one – they went searching. To pray for a mate and “meet” someone…it could be from God. But only we know what we pray for and how we pray for it and where we place ourselves in order to receive it. 
 
By what measure can a belief in the supernatural be substantiated? Doesn't substantiate imply physical evidence or physical existence?
 
 Websters Main Entry: sub·stan·ti·ate 
 1 : to give substance or form to : EMBODY
 2 : to establish by proof or competent evidence : VERIFY 
 
 This implies that belief in God, by definition, can never be substantiated. It can only be accepted through faith. Individuals may offer their perceptions of personal experiences as evidence that establishes the existence of God, but replace one individual with another individual in the same set of circumstances, and you may get a completely different perception of the exact same personal experience.

 The only gauge to monitor is that measure by which we receive things from our belief. If we see that our life is in complete alignment with the scriptures and are following all the precepts of His will, then we can rest assured that God will take care of His end of the bargain. If not, then go back and review the reasons why. Maybe you’ve lost faith or maybe there’s something happening or has happened that just shouldn’t be happening to a child of God, which makes you doubt Him and/or His ways. Maybe something in scripture just isn’t agreeing with itself for you and you find that if one mistake is made in the Bible – maybe it’s all wrong. You don’t stop and figure out the problem (maybe it’s that certain problem that can thrust even more forward in faith), but instead, you become afraid and give up.
 God said that faith without works is dead. If He can say that towards us, then we must accept that our faith in Him must be substantiated through His works. It is our duty, our responsibility to test Him – we’ve done our part and should expect Him to do His. That’s okay by Him, He wants that. Without it all the belief we can muster is worthless. Do we have to be pure as the driven snow, spotless and without sin? No. What did jitobear say in billsco’s Halloween thread? “The good Lord is not a child, if I can understand intent, he surely can.” God knows us…and we need to be able to understand ourselves as much as He does.
 
Ron, I'm curious whether this is an easily imagineable hypothetical, or if you are aware of a specific instance of this happening. My 97 year old grandmother died recently. She was a very spiritual woman -- spending many hours a day in prayer. She seemed to be struggling with 'letting go' toward the end, and I wondered whether she may have been dealing with this most fundamental question.

 Purely hypothetical, but possible. Wouldn’t you agree?
 Your grandmother could have been on a mission that she had not fully completed. Maybe she felt that there was just one more thing she needed to do. In all her years and in all those hours of prayer, she probably had insight into scripture and for our reason(s) for being here more than anyone. When so many are left “out there” without the truth, the human instinct is to save just one more – when that close to God. That is my take on it.
 
You attempt to make a distinction here between superstition and belief in God. However... let's take the same thing in the context of a superstition that you said about 'true belief in God.' 
 
 For example, belief that touching a photo of a lost loved one everyday upon waking -- true belief -- will result in you spending a glorious, eternal afterlife with that person. So, you do this everyday, because you do not want to lose the opportunity to spend eternity with your loved one. It takes a lifetime of doing this to test whether or not it has any merit. Every once in awhile, you experience signs... like the smell of your loved one's favorite flowers at the very moment you were touching the photo or at the very moment you were thinking of the person. Or maybe life is getting you down, but then you think of your loved one and the prospect of spending a glorious eternity with them, and that thought alone cheers you up. Then one day, you forget to touch the picture, and you happen to get into a car accident. And you have a 'vision' of your loved one being sad because you forgot to touch the picture, but they reassure you in this vision that as long as you are truly sorry, you will be forgiven and you can still continue to touch the picture everyday, and everything will be okay.
 
 In this example the individual's experience can certainly be perceived to substantiate the belief of touching the picture = glorious eternity with loved one. How is this different than a belief in God?

 Unfortunately there are people that put faith in things like that. In my experience it becomes more an addiction than a belief, but I will take it from there, as you stated, and reply with what I believe.
 If a person believes that our spirit can become detached from us, leaving just a shell, then they have no concept of the meaning of “life”. Our inner person needs to believe in something in order to survive this cruel world. Some find this out early, some late, and for some it takes a lifetime. Unfortunately some never do accept it. But for those that rely on physical things to bring them peace it all too soon becomes a god to them. They begin to worship it, knowingly or not, and begin to rely on it for strength. And even though it brings them comfort and those old familiar feelings now and then, it cannot give them “life”. It cannot give them what they need. The biggest problem I see with the photo analogy is that it can burn up, be stolen, or just rubbed out in time. That holds true with those that have found a hollow god and why I can relate to someone finding the belief in God just a superstition. I have heard so many times: “Just give me one more reason to believe, just one more, and I’ll live like You want me to, Lord.” That prayer gets answered, but sadly they don’t place themselves in position to realize it.
zachvac

you dont have to believe that something is true before you test it. in everyday life its usually the opposite way around. with God, yes, it is required you have faith that he will "pass the test" before you test him. and even if you dont see the results you expect, you must still be totally convinced that he "passed the test"

 
 Exactly. And it's the same kind of thing with Horroscopes. They are so vague something like "your love life will decline". There are so many events that could be thought to be associated with that. With praying and a good thing happening, I could do the same with breaking a mirror. Say I broke a mirror on my birthday and 6 years later right before the time you broke it you get a gift you don't like. Then after it's been exactly 6 years your parents give you a car. Sounds like that could be proof of the 6 years thing. Especially since plenty of bad luck probably happened in between there.
Alan Ryan

Belief in God - true belief - means testing God, seeing if He listens, then getting results. How long does that take? For some a lifetime. 

 OK. I would never knock or insult people who believe in God. If their faith
 brings them hope and comfort in a suffering world, then I can't see any
 harm in that - provided this faith remains a private conviction. But if or
 when religious faith influences public policy (in education etc.), then other
 considerations begin to apply.
 Having said this first, I still cannot detect any difference between a deep-
 rooted but unfounded belief ( a superstition), and the "true belief" in which
 you place your confidence.
Big Orn

But if or when religious faith influences public policy (in education etc.), then other considerations begin to apply.

 We agree here. Religion can be a nasty business. And I feel that if there did come a day that the Bible was taught in schools again that it would be left up to the regions/districts. There is no religion that is or could be agreed upon nationally that could be introduced into schools.
 
Having said this first, I still cannot detect any difference between a deep-
 rooted but unfounded belief ( a superstition), and the "true belief" in which
 you place your confidence.

 It is hard to grasp. I understand.
billsco

And I feel that if there did come a day that the Bible was taught in schools again that it would be left up to the regions/districts. There is no religion that is or could be agreed upon nationally that could be introduced into schools.
 
 

 
 Bad idea there, Big O. I strongly disagree. We should never teach our children anything we don't know for sure. Religious instruction doesn't fit that bill. We would begin to see a country becoming more divided by regional biases with each new generation, with no remedy in sight and powerless to overcome it. 
 
 I'm for strong, big federal government in tiny schoolhouses.
Big Orn

Bad idea there, Big O. I strongly disagree. We should never teach our children anything we don't know for sure. Religious instruction doesn't fit that bill. We would begin to see a country becoming more divided by regional biases with each new generation, with no remedy in sight and powerless to overcome it. 
 
 I'm for strong, big federal government in tiny schoolhouses.

 I can see your point. I'm afraid that there would be some sort of hidden agenda in religion these days - not like it was in the 60's when Mrs. Grubbs knew just what to say...and not say.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Difference between superstition & belief in God?
